pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Vector Math clear and mostly easy to follow, with a few areas of confusion. The main topics discussed were the use of sine and cosine functions, stacking vectors head to tail, and subtracting vectors. Some students struggled with understanding when to use sine or cosine, and how to apply unit vectors. A few also expressed confusion about subtracting vectors, particularly in the context of the Yeti problem and Top Hat questions. The use of Top Hat for interactive questions was also a point of confusion for some students, with a few missing partial points due to uncertainty about submission times. Overall, students appreciated the clear explanations and found the lecture efficient, with some suggestions for additional examples and clarification on specific topics.
input:
Just a quick review of when to use sin vs cos in vector math and which angles to apply, depending on which function is chosen (just because they are, technically, interchangeable)
How to stack the vectors from head to tail. When is it allowed, and when is it not?
Today's lecture was clear and for the most part easy to follow. The only part that I still am confused on is using unit vectors. However, I believe this will be covered in more detail with the next lecture.
I was confused about angle conversions in this lecture. I understand that you add based off of what quadrant the vector is in, but on an in-class example that rule didn't work, and I needed to subtract 360°. 
I think it would be more beneficial if you would go in depth of your pictures drawn and explain how they apply to a numerical problem even more.
I didn't find anything confusing or unclear during today's class. I have already taken 2 years of physics, so I know this content very well and is something I'm very comfortable with. I believe the way you taught it is very similar to how I first learned the material.
One thing I will definitely need to be looking more in to is the subtraction of vectors from the Yeti problem, when solving on my own i had a slightly different answer, so I will be trying to figure out why.
Overall, the lecture was efficient and assessed everything that was taught throughout the online lecture videos. However, going a little slower throughout the problems to let students understand and catch up through every step will allow for more information absorption. Also, during the top hat questions, it could've been more informative to go over why the incorrect answers were actually wrong.
I believe that what is most confusing to me about the lecture is when to use sin and cos for x and y, and occasionally where to put the angle given. I think i confuse myself when it comes to sin and cos. 
I was initially confused on how subtracting vectors worked but I figured it out
 Nothing extremely confusing this time around. Just to make sure, whenever you need to find the vector from one tip of a vector to another one, when both are going in a different direction from the origin, you have to subtract, right?
 I thought today's class went very well. I do not think that I did not misunderstand any of the topics discussed during the class. I found the problem we did in breakout rooms very helpful because it allowed for my group and I to think for ourselves.
 How the right-hand rule can be manipulated to apply to the cross product and how unit vectors create a direction.
 I am familiar with vectors which was the topic of the lecture. I thought the professor gave enough details for me. 
 There was nothing that proved to be confusing or unclear in today's class. 
 There wasn't anything really confusing about today's lecture. I had a little trouble with the top hat questions however I seemed to get the hang of it by the end. I liked that the teacher drew the graphs and vectors. 
 I was confused by the question about the atoms whose positions were represented by vectors stemming from the same origin. The idea of vectors representing positions led me to believe it was a collision problem so I struggled to set it up.
 When values should be positive or negative and when it is necessary to add 180 to an angle. 
 I'm confused about the direction a negative vector points when it is added to a positive vector. 
 I didn't find anything that was confusing. The content videos before the lecture were very helpful for preparing.
 Vectors are very confusing to me.  They were explained very well, I just have issues understanding how to start the problems and use the equations with the information given. 
 When given a word problem like the one example of the players hitting the puck how can you easily get an idea of what direction the vector would be going in
 I thought the first top hat question was difficult and I still think my answer could have been correct.  How could you know from the information in the question the the two vectors were headed in the same direction?
 Sometimes I felt like issues with TopHat (not always my own) took away from the explanation of answers, but these are just temporary as we all get used to the format.
 Most of the material covered today is content I have seen before so it was not confusing at all. The clicker questions were explained clearly. They only thing that is sometimes confusing is navigating canvas.
 didn't have much trouble with any of the concepts presented in the lecture today. I have taken physics so this was a pretty basic review
 There honestly wasn't anything that was notably confusing or lacking in detail. (We're also working on vector basics in Calc 3 though, so it's possible that there was simply a lot of fortuitous overlap.)
 Today's video was good. I was confused throughout the video on how to know whether or not to subtract or add vectors based on the specific question, but I believe that is more so me understanding the problem and how to properly draw out the graph and vectors and understanding what the question is asking us to do than the actual math itself. Therefore I believe that with additional lectures and practice I will have it down!
 Most everything was described clearly, including teaching style, content, and Canvas. For me personally, I still had questions by the end of the lecture about what/how to use Piazza, TopHat, and Sapling. Luckily, everything was figured out by our second meeting through your clarification and other students help. 
 How the direction of a resultant vector compares to the value. I have trouble understanding their relationship.
 This was the first class with introductions and an overview of the course. I think my professor did a great job of explaining the course criteria and the websites we will be using throughout the semester.
 The only thing I found confusing in today's lecture was the second top hat question we did. I was confused about how to determine whether we would add the vectors or subtract them. 
 There was nothing confusing to me in today's lecture.
 The first multiple choice question confused me today. I was not sure how to do it or where to start but after the explanation I understand why the answer was B. 
 I was a little confused about the way tophat worked at the beginning of the lecture and how much time we would have for each part but after I used it for the first question I got the hang of it. 
 Everything was explained very well and in detail. I used law of sines and cosines for some problems but that's just cause I prefer it that way. 
 The only new thing to me was the idea of subtracting vectors. For example the top hat question was asking if you would add or subtract/which way you would subtract. However, with examples I was able to understand. I did like the breakout groups and getting to discuss with classmates. I also wish that the comment section was geared more towards questions and not comments because questions can get lost. Thanks.
 How, even with having to visualizing a resultant vector, the two addition vectors do not need to be visualized tip to tail.
 I thought today's lecture was good. One thing I'd like clarification on is vector notation if it hasn't already been specified in the question. Will you expect a specific notion? Will you expect the (i, j, k) notation or is arrow(<x,y>) acceptable too? 
 Our first lecture was not co fusing. We talked about the syllabus, how grading works, how extra credit is assigned, and what programs to install. The only confusing part is making sure we have all the software and books we need. Something that could help with that is a checklist.
 I had a bit of trouble interacting with others in the breakout rooms, but that is something I will work on improving myself. 
 I just don't understand when we subtract and don't add. I understand why we have to subtract certain ways but when do we subtract? 
 It seemed like some people didn't quite know how Tophat was going to work, and missed out on partial question points by not submitting an answer. Maybe another quick recap of the program and grading policies before starting the first question would be useful.
 I am still having some difficulties adding and subtracting vectors geometrically which also goes along with making the vector drawings for word problems. 
 Using Top Hat/getting used to using Top Hat was a bit confusing and tough. I wasn't always sure when to submit answers, how much time I had, and I had some trouble getting out of the zoom window quickly and to the Top Hat one. I think the more practice I get with it though the better I'll get at it.

For example, in the yeti problem I did not know if you were supposed to add the two vectors or subtract them. The same goes for the Top Hat question earlier. in class regarding RA and RB. My instinct is to always add it it confuses me on when to subtract.
 Nothing from this video lecture was particularly unclear. It would be helpful to have more problems where unit vectors are used and/or examples of their overall use in physics. 
 Just needed back in the swing of all the trig functions. Haven't used them too much in about a year. 
 everything made sense, I didn't find anything confusing
 I have difficulty figuring out which direction (as in North of East or South of West) the resulting vector is pointing.
 In the Vector Basics section maybe include a position vs. time graph problem with questions related to trying to find speed and velocity in order to really highlight the difference between scalars and vectors in the scope of this class. Additionally the Adding and Subtracting Vectors by Components could use another example on how to arrange the arrows to suit a given equation when they are all out of order. (Side note: on the concept quizzes, I feel like there should be a note that you only have one opportunity to get full points, following that you'll lose points for each attempt.)
 The information was explained in an easy to understand manner. However, I would like more information on negative vectors and how they affect the problem when the resultant gets moved around. I know you said that negative vectors wouldn't be used much but I still think it was a confusing topic. Thank you!
 Something that was confusing about today's video lecture was how in some cases with inverse tangent, you must add 180 degrees to your answer. I understand that this can be seen with the graph of tangent, but I'm not sure how you know when you should trust your answer or know that u have to add 180 degrees. 
 The lecture was overall very clear. The only part I found slightly confusing was the unit vectors, specially the purpose they serve, since it is just multiplying by 1.
 The video lectures were thorough about how to do the math for vectors. The thing that is confusing was the identification of scalars and vectors specifically if scalars need units or not.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the TopHat questions challenging, with many expressing confusion about when to use vector addition (tip-to-tail) and when to use vector subtraction (head-to-tail), particularly in the context of the Yeti problem and the first TopHat question. Students struggled with determining whether to add or subtract based on the specific context and requirements of each problem, not just the vectors involved. Some also mentioned difficulty in understanding the direction of the resultant vector. A few students had trouble navigating the TopHat platform, suggesting that a brief recap or tutorial on using TopHat at the beginning of the next lecture could help students become more comfortable with the platform.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the application of Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) engaging, particularly in solving problems involving pulley systems, where forces acting on an object were clearly visualized. They appreciated the "recipe" for drawing FBDs, making the process more intuitive. The concept of forces having resisting components and the ability to change the system analyzed to simplify calculations were also highlighted as interesting aspects. Students enjoyed the conceptual problems and group activities, such as the ice problem and top hat questions, which challenged their understanding and encouraged collaboration.
input:
The different applications of FBD to solve problems like the example of the man supporting himself on the pulley system.

Despite this being a difficult concept, i though the man pulling himself up with a pulley was very interesting, as it shows how pulleys can be utilized in industry 
top hat

drawing free body diagrams to set up equations

**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate Redundancies**: Combine similar points to make the summary more concise. For instance, merge the points about the man pulling himself up with half his weight and the pulley system making it easier to lift things.

refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the application of free body diagrams (FBDs) to pulley and elevator problems engaging and insightful. They were particularly intrigued by the counterintuitive result that a person can lift themselves with only half their weight using a pulley system, as demonstrated in the man in the chair problem. The concept of tension in ropes, with equal forces acting on both ends, was also fascinating. Students valued the strategic use of FBDs and changing the system or coordinate axes to simplify calculations and better understand these real-life relevant problems. Interactive Top Hat questions and breakout room problems further enhanced their engagement and understanding of the topic.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of redefining systems in the context of free body diagrams (FBDs) and pulley systems particularly engaging. They appreciated learning how to analyze multiple objects as a single system, simplifying calculations and providing new insights. This approach was illustrated in problems like the man pulling himself up with a pulley, where the system was redefined to include the man and the pulley, reducing the force required to half his weight. Students also found it intriguing that changing the coordinate system could make problems easier to solve. The interactive nature of the lecture, including group tests and breakout room problems, further enhanced their understanding and enjoyment of the topic.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on two blocks and forces/systems engaging but challenging, with several top hat questions sparking confusion. The primary sticking points were conceptual understanding and application of forces, particularly when multiple forces were involved, such as in stacked blocks or blocks on inclines. Students struggled with combining free body diagrams for multiple blocks and determining which forces to consider. Some also expressed difficulty in differentiating between static and kinetic friction and identifying when to use each. Despite these challenges, students appreciated the practical examples and exam questions provided, requesting more time for problem-solving and clearer explanations for complex concepts.
input:
Friction on an incline was what confused me. When more than one or two forces are applied, I feel like things are bound to get confusing. 
I found the top hat question about the two blocks hanging from the pulley the most confusing just because I understood it when I set the tensions equal to each other but not conceptually 
stacked bodys
Figuring out all the different forces that go with boxes next to each other together 
Everything was clear, just the problem with the bottom block accelerating was hard
I didn't find any of the material confusing or unclear, good lecture today
The last example with two blocks and one sliding on the other was confusing 
I was confused by the question with the two blocks where the bottom block had no friction. 
Sometimes finding the force needed to move a block, but this was typically for more complicated problems.

2. **Specify the confusion with stacked blocks**: While the original summary mentions stacked blocks as a source of confusion, it would be more helpful to specify that students were confused about the force needed to move the top block when there's friction between the blocks.

A few students mentioned that the lecture ran out of time before they could fully grasp the problem, and they would have benefited from more time spent on it.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Specific Confusions**: Instead of generalizing that students struggled with complex scenarios, specify the most confusing situations mentioned by students, such as:
   - "Combining FBDs for multiple objects, especially when one object is on top of another."
   - "Determining which forces to include, particularly friction forces."
   - "Calculating forces needed to move one block relative to another, especially when friction is involved."

2. **Emphasize the Need for Detailed Worked Examples**: Instead of a general request for more practice problems, highlight the specific type of examples students asked for:
   - "More detailed worked examples involving multiple blocks and surfaces, with clear explanations of how FBDs are constructed and forces are calculated."
   - "Examples that demonstrate how to split a problem into multiple systems and combine FBDs."

3. **Address Misconceptions About Friction**: Rather than mentioning uncertainty about friction concepts, address the specific misconceptions and questions raised by students:
   - "Clarify the difference between static and kinetic friction, and the concept of maximum static friction, with real-world examples."
   - "Explain why the coefficient of friction is unitless and how it works."
   - "Discuss when to use fs (friction of static) and fs_max, and why we find fs_max instead of just using fs."
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on Free Body Diagrams (FBDs) mostly clear, but several specific aspects caused confusion. The primary challenges were:

1. **Combining FBDs for Multiple Objects:** Students struggled with constructing FBDs for systems involving multiple blocks or surfaces, particularly when one object was on top of another. They found it difficult to determine which forces to include, especially friction forces, and how to combine the FBDs for each object.

2. **Calculating Forces with Friction:** Students had trouble calculating forces needed to move one block relative to another, especially when friction was involved. They needed more guidance on how to apply friction forces in their FBDs and use them to solve for unknown forces.

3. **Understanding Friction Concepts:** Students expressed misconceptions and uncertainty about the difference between static and kinetic friction, the concept of maximum static friction (fs_max), and why we use fs_max instead of just fs. They also questioned why the coefficient of friction is unitless and how it works in real-world scenarios.

To address these issues, students requested:

- **Detailed Worked Examples:** More detailed worked examples involving multiple blocks and surfaces, with clear explanations of how FBDs are constructed, forces are calculated, and how to split a problem into multiple systems and combine FBDs.

- **Clarification of Friction Concepts:** Clear explanations and real-world examples to help students understand the difference between static and kinetic friction, the concept of fs_max, and the unitless nature of the coefficient of friction.

- **Additional Time and Practice:** More time for conceptual questions and practice problems in class, as well as access to exam-style questions for self-study.

By focusing on these specific areas, the instructor can better address student confusions and provide tailored support to help students improve their understanding and application of Free Body Diagrams.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the Top Hat questions engaging and helpful in solidifying their understanding of concepts like tension, Newton's laws, and reference frames. The interactive nature of the questions, such as the spaceship and tug-of-war scenarios, allowed them to apply theoretical knowledge to real-world situations, making the learning experience more enjoyable and memorable. The group work and breakout rooms were also appreciated for fostering collaborative problem-solving. However, some students noted that the time allocated for answering questions could be slightly increased to allow for more thorough discussions.

FBD

what was most interesting was the examples that we had in class. they were helpful

Tension

Free body diagrams, force problems in general, complex problems, free body diagrams

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of centripetal force challenging and desired more clarification, particularly regarding why the acceleration vector points inwards and how to determine centripetal force. The application of centripetal force in circular motion, especially in problems involving drag force and density changes, caused confusion. Some students struggled with conceptualizing and setting up equations for drag force problems, while others found the transition between uniform and non-uniform circular motion confusing. A few students also expressed concern about understanding the units of drag force and the role of centripetal force as a 'force'.
input:
Centripetal force was confusing and we spent very little time on it
I need more clarification about why the acceleration vector points in toward the center. 
Circular motion, centripetal force, equations relating to circular motion
I thought the problem with the skydiver into the ocean was confusing because there were too many variables.
The last example problem we did with the string and mass. I thought we didn't spend as much time on it as I would've liked. 
I struggled with the idea of how each variable impacts the overall equation for the drag force.
The most confusing part of the lecture was determining the centripetal force. 
Circular force was a bit confusing when dealing with acceleration. 
I was a little confused by the application of acceleration at an instant when terminal velocity changes. However, your explanation cleared it up. The application of multiple g's tripped me up and I got the practice problem incorrect as I forgot a g. 
I thought the question on terminal velocity was confusing. I was confused on how to set up the equation so that all the unknown variables would end up cancelling.
 I think it was tough to conceptualize some of the drag force problems. Although it's not going to be a heavy focus for the exam, I would've liked to connect more drag force problems to conceptual ideas.
 I found the example problem where the guy hits the water very confusing because of dealing with two different  densities. 
 What was confusing about this lecture was what forces can be considered a centripetal force.  I saw that soletimes it can be the normal force or some other force.
 Circular motion/centripetal force caused by friction
 The example involving the acceleration and drag force on the jumper in the ocean.
 How circular motion works, and how the forces interact.
 Circular motion and how objects move around the circle
 The problem where the person was hitting the water confused me... I thought that because they were entering the water then mg would no longer be acting on them and the only force acting would be drag force
 The explanation of deriving the equations was confusing because it moved very quickly.
 The terminal velocity question with the difference in air and water density was challenging to see at first. 
 I was confused on the units for drag force 
 Today's lesson was not unclear or confusing. The only thing that could have been explained more in depth is centripetal force.
 I am still unclear about terminal velocity and when it is used. 
 the lesson moved really fast for such a complicated topic. deriving the equations was confusing and there weren't enough examples or applications to understand the formulas
 i found the centripetal problems a little confusing today. i think I just would like to see it more. besides that it was good. 
 A hard thing to understand is when a terminal velocity begins and ends when entering or exiting different substances.
 The first example of the terminal velocity and the acceleration before the man contacts the water.

 I don't get how velocity changes when you switch between materials.

 How the drag coefficient density of air and water can be in the same equation simultaneously 
 circular motion was barely even taught, especially the net force portion 
 On the first top hat group question finding the equation and what cancelled out 
 I think more explanation should be there for the top hat examples. I was confused at a few steps.
 Normal force on the top of a hill
 I thought the last two top hat questions were confusing 
 Trying to solve a problem with very to no numbers given and having to figure out the algebra and forces 
 The problem with sonic going around in a circle confused me because it i didn't understand why it wasn't gravity 
 Tension problems could use some more examples like like a ball on a string moving in a circular path what is theta if given length of string, mass, and r maybe.
 the difference between uniform and nonuniform circular motion
 Nothing was really confusing in today's lecture
 Drag force, in particular, knowing when to substitute

 I'm confused on how centripetal force isn't an actual force.
 the effect of density on the terminal velocity
 Some of the components of drag force are a little confusing because I'm not totally sure how they all affect the overall drag.
 I would like more details on combining circular motion with free body diagrams in three dimensions, and I would like to know how much we need to know about doing derivatives of various equations.

 The drag force formula was confusing. I guess this is just because we haven't seen many of the things in it before. I'm just a little unclear as to what the units are for each one.

Students sought more clarification, additional examples, and in-depth explanations to solidify their understanding of circular motion, centripetal force, and drag force.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Eliminate repetitive phrases**: Instead of repeatedly mentioning "in-class activity", refer to it once at the beginning and use "activity" or "task" thereafter. This will make the summary more concise.

   *Original*: "Students expressed varying levels of clarity regarding the in-class activity..."

   *Revised*: "Students had varying clarity regarding the in-class activity, with some finding it straightforward while others struggled to understand the task at hand."

2. **Combine similar confusions**: Group similar confusions together to streamline the summary. For instance, combine confusions about criteria and metrics, and about the template and required parts.

   *Original*: "Key confusions included distinguishing between criteria and metrics, determining which parts of the template to complete, and how to choose and score criteria."

   *Revised*: "Key confusions revolved around understanding the distinction between criteria and metrics, and determining what parts of the template were required for completion."

3. **Use transitional phrases**: To improve flow and connect ideas, use transitional phrases like "Moreover", "Additionally", or "Furthermore".

   *Original*: "Some suggested having TAs join breakout rooms... while others found the class clear and enjoyable."

   *Revised*: "Moreover, some students suggested having TAs join breakout rooms for further discussion, while others found the class clear and enjoyable."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students had varying clarity regarding the in-class activity, with some finding it straightforward while others struggled to understand the task at hand. Key confusions revolved around understanding the distinction between criteria and metrics, and determining what parts of the template were required for completion. Additionally, the weighted decision matrix (WDM) proved challenging for some students, particularly when attempting to fill it out before learning about it in detail. Moreover, some students suggested having TAs join breakout rooms for further discussion, while others found the class clear and enjoyable.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on histograms, graphs, and charts engaging and informative. They appreciated learning when and how to use different types of graphs to represent various datasets, with a particular focus on histograms. The in-class activity involving individual thoughts, whole class discussions, and breakout room collaborations was well-received. Students enjoyed using Excel to create and manipulate histograms, finding it a powerful tool with a high learning curve. They also found it interesting to learn about comparing two sets of data with one graph and calculating appropriate bin size and number for histograms. Many students highlighted the helpfulness of the spider chart that outlined which chart to use with different data types.

Suggestions:

1. **Eliminate Redundancies**: Combine similar student reflections to make the summary more concise. For instance, instead of mentioning "interesting" multiple times, you could say "students found the activity engaging and insightful, with many expressing surprise at their individual impacts."

2. **Focus on Key Findings**: Highlight the most significant findings from the reflections. For example, emphasize that some students found they would need multiple Earths to sustain their current lifestyles if everyone lived like them. This could be rephrased as "students were particularly struck by the revelation that some would require multiple Earths to support their current lifestyles if everyone lived similarly."

3. **Clarify the Impact of the Activity**: Instead of stating that the activity sparked interest in understanding personal energy consumption and the need for change, be more specific. For instance, "the activity prompted students to consider their daily habits and the role of engineers in mitigating climate change." This makes the summary more focused on the learning outcomes of the activity.

Nothing was really confusing except how we were put in breakout rooms for a bit and then taken out of them for an announcement that could have just be typed in chat so we didn't have to leave breakout rooms. It would have let us keep our train of thought

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the breakout rooms to be a valuable and engaging aspect of the lecture. They appreciated the opportunity to meet and interact with fellow students, fostering a sense of community and comfort in the class. The breakout rooms facilitated deeper discussions and allowed students to express their thoughts more freely than they might have in a larger group setting. Many students also found the activity they completed within these groups to be thought-provoking and enjoyable.
input:
I found the class to be interesting and interactive. I enjoyed meeting fellow students as this helped me to feel more comfortable and overall welcome in the class.
The class activity was interesting. 
Getting to know the professor and the peers
I loved the breakout rooms and the chance to meet new people. I also found the activity we did very interesting as well because I didn't expect the questions you asked us afterwards to be so thought-provoking. 
I liked how we went over what the course would look like and who we could contact for help.
I found the breakout groups to be the most interesting. I had never used them before so it was a good learning experience.
I enjoyed the breakout sessions. They really allowed me to talk more in-depth with specific people, rather than just watching the instructor. It made the whole experience a lot more initiating and interactive. 
The people I met in my group 
I thought that the layout of the course was interesting and the activity of drawing our view of an engineer was very interesting. The layout is 4 main projects and I thought that it was cool to be in that format rather than many smaller projects. The drawing was interesting because it made you look to the future.
The most interesting thing I found was the logistics of the class and how we are supposed to complete projects

The Taum Sauk project, mathematical models, and the laminar approach were particularly puzzling. To enhance understanding, students suggested and would benefit from:

1. **Explicit Variable Guidance**: Clearly outline which variables to use and why in assignment descriptions to alleviate student uncertainty.

2. **Illustrative Examples**: Including more examples or case studies in assignment descriptions, especially for complex topics like the laminar approach and mathematical models, would provide valuable context and clarification.

3. **Step-by-Step Breakdowns**: Breaking down complex tasks into smaller, manageable steps in assignment descriptions could make them less overwhelming and more accessible to students.

4. **Purpose and Relevance**: Explaining the purpose and relevance of assignments in the descriptions can help students understand the 'why' behind the tasks, fostering engagement and better comprehension of expectations.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on engineering failures engaging, with the Taum Sauk reservoir case study being particularly insightful. They appreciated understanding the causes of these failures, which ranged from negligence and unethical shortcuts to communication breakdowns and lack of oversight. The real-world implications of these failures resonated with students, highlighting the importance of thorough analysis, attention to detail, and ethical practices in engineering. Many enjoyed working in groups to explore these failures and their preventability.
input:
I enjoyed the discussion about engineering failures. I wish we had spent more time on discussing what choices resulted in the failures.
I found the engineering failures for the Taum Sauk reservoir to be an insightful example of how engineering projects can go badly based on negligence and lack of proper ethics by engineers involved in orchestrating it.
What I enjoyed most in this class was working on the project with my peers.
Learning about different engineering disasters and going into detail about how things went wrong was interesting 
i thought constructures experts make can also be fallen
It was a straightforward and informational lesson with work time, and thus did not have much interesting or now knowledge. 
I found it interesting that such little flaws in engineering design or communication can lead to such drastic and catastrophic failures of mechanisms and projects. It really shows the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives.
The most interesting part about todays class was working on Assignment 12 and making the different tables for each analysis of data that we needed to do.
I found the discussion over real world disasters to be interesting because it showed how the actions of engineers could have ramifications outside of not getting a good grade.
The reservoir was super flawed and had a ton of issues with oversight and basic land surveying.

 Working on the in class activity was interesting because I got to research the TAUM Sauk failure. 
 How oversights in the engineering of structures can lead to massive failures

 I found all of the engineering failures interesting because it shows how much damage an error can cause even if it isn't noticeable or paid attention to at first. I found it to be a kind of challenge for future engineers to not be lazy and not cut corners.
 I found it really interesting how most disasters in engineering are entirely presentable.
 I found it interesting when we were talking about all of the engineering failures because we took a closer look at why some of the biggest mistakes in engineering history occurred. 
 What was interesting about today's class was seeing just how crucial communication and attention to detail is when something so minimal can cause a huge disaster.

These examples helped highlight the important of team communication and keeping track of what you have done and still need to do.
 when rebuilding the dam, the company again refused to spend more money to add one.

Suggestions:

1. **Eliminate Repetition**: The summary mentions "engineering failures" and "Taum Sauk Reservoir" multiple times. To make it more concise, consider using phrases like "the reservoir's failure" or "the case study" instead of repeating the reservoir's name.

   *Revised*: "Students found the analysis of the reservoir's failure and other engineering disasters engaging..."

2. **Focus on Student Learning**: The original summary starts with what students found engaging. Instead, begin with what they learned to emphasize the educational value of the topic.

   *Revised*: "Students learned the importance of thorough analysis, attention to detail, and ethical decision-making in preventing engineering disasters like the reservoir's failure..."

3. **Highlight Specific Causes**: To make the summary more focused on the Tom Sauk Reservoir, mention one or two specific causes of its failure that students found interesting or insightful.

   *Revised*: "...students found it insightful to explore specific causes of the reservoir's failure, such as negligence in land surveying and cutting corners on safety measures."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students learned the importance of thorough analysis, attention to detail, and ethical decision-making in preventing engineering disasters like the reservoir's failure. They found it insightful to explore specific causes of the reservoir's failure, such as negligence in land surveying and cutting corners on safety measures, and appreciated understanding how these oversights led to catastrophic consequences. The real-world implications of these failures resonated with students, highlighting the significance of their role as future engineers. The interactive nature of the class, including group work and breakout rooms, was also well-received, providing an engaging platform for students to discuss and learn from these case studies.

pred: SUMMARY: While many students found the lecture clear, several expressed confusion regarding Assignment 10 and the In-Class Activity 10. The primary concerns were unclear expectations for the assignment, particularly parts 4 and 5 involving mathematical models and the laminar approach. Students also struggled with identifying reliable sources for the in-class activity and understanding the citation process. Some found the technical brief confusing, especially the Taum Sauk upper reservoir sketch. Time management during the in-class activity was another challenge for some students.

It was all pretty clear, there wasn't much that I was confused about in this lecture

What was confusing about this class, was how are we supposed to know if to include something we think is a  constraint is one for the company too?

I was confused around the in class activity. How do you find peer reviewed or reliable sources on more general information. All papers seem to be on specific topics.

I didn't really understand which sources were acceptable for this class. I know which sources are more reliable than others, but not which degree of reliability is acceptable for class assignments.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify Acceptable Sources and Citation Guidelines:** To address the confusion about acceptable sources and citations, consider providing a concise list of acceptable sources and a brief guide on how to cite them in the next class or through an announcement. This could include examples of acceptable sources (e.g., peer-reviewed journals, reputable websites) and a simple guide on how to determine the reliability of a source.

2. **Dedicate Time to In-Class Activity Explanation:** To alleviate confusion about the in-class activity, consider dedicating more time to explaining the activity, its objectives, and the expected outcomes. This could also include a brief walkthrough of how to find and cite reliable sources for general information.

3. **Provide Examples for Laminar Approach and Mathematical Models:** To help students understand the laminar approach and mathematical models, provide clear examples or a step-by-step guide on how to apply these concepts in the context of Assignment 10. This could be done through a short video tutorial or additional resources posted on the course website.
refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students sought clarity on scholarly work and citations, particularly for Assignment 10 and the in-class activity. Key areas of confusion included:

1. **Acceptable Sources and Citation:** Students struggled to identify suitable sources and apply appropriate citation formats. To address this, consider providing a list of acceptable sources and a concise citation guide, including examples, in the next class or through an announcement.

2. **Reliable Sources for General Information:** Students found it challenging to locate reliable sources for general information. Allocating more time in the next class to explain strategies for finding and evaluating such sources would be beneficial.

3. **Laminar Approach and Mathematical Models:** Students requested more explanation and examples to understand and apply these concepts in Assignment 10. Providing clear examples or a step-by-step guide through additional resources or a short video tutorial could help clarify these topics.

By focusing on these areas, the instructor can help students better understand and navigate scholarly work and citations, ultimately enhancing their learning experience.

The new project on analyzing solar energy usage for the Indianapolis Library was met with enthusiasm, as students looked forward to applying their knowledge to a real-world scenario and making data-driven design decisions. 2. **Highlight unique aspects**: While real-world application and data-driven decisions were mentioned, emphasize the unique constraint of the project's location (Indianapolis Library) and its impact on solar energy payback, as this was a notable reflection from several students.

3. **Simplify the summary structure**: Break down the summary into clear, distinct points to improve focus and readability. For example:
   - Students appreciated the real-world application and data-driven approach of the new project.

pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found the lecture on car carbon emissions engaging and informative. The in-class activity, where they calculated their cars' emissions, was particularly impactful. Students appreciated the connection drawn between their personal actions and global climate change. They also found the discussion on design trade-offs interesting, understanding that engineers must balance various factors, including environmental impact.

This understanding helped them appreciate the complex decisions engineers must make in their designs.

3. **Engineers' Role**: To make this point more concise and focused, consider combining it with the previous suggestion: "Through hands-on activities and discussions, students understood the significant role engineers play in addressing climate change, with many expressing a newfound responsibility to consider environmental impacts in their future work." Overall, students desired more detailed explanations and guidance for each assignment.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion and clarification of Assignment 17 extremely helpful, with many teams acknowledging they would have struggled without the in-class guidance. input:
I found the group time and the discussion about the assignment most interesting. The clarifications made in class were helpful 
I found the advice on how to do the activity incredibly helpful. My team was wrongly doing the activity, and without the clarification likely would have turned it in without meeting the requirements.
It was interesting to see how going over the pros and cons for an idea can change designs. 
I enjoyed the idea of the in class activity despite the poor topic. It was good practice in determining pros and cons.
I liked the evaluation of pros/cons of the costumer service. I think maybe you could give us questions to think about if we need to further evaluate pros/cons for any project 
I found our discussion of pros and cons very interesting today, especially when it came to how they related to engineering 
This whole design project really appeals to me and I'm excited to draw out the sketches for my group.
Going over what we should do in assignment 17 was extremely helpful to my team. We would have done the assignment incorrectly if we hadn't gone over the assignment expectations in class. 
Not many things happened today, I did like the in class activity which made me think outside the box.
I found the thought experiments very interesting because they will be very useful when thinking about the ideas we generate for A17. 
 I enjoyed coming up with ideas and thought it was interesting to see how my teamates thoughts varied.
 There wasn't much that was that interesting, again kind of a brief lesson and then plenty of work time. 
 I found the thought exercises on pros and cons interesting. The ups and downs to each solution having so much variability depending on the perceived values.
 The french press / Keurig assignment was intriguing and I think I learned more about coffee from it.
 I found idea generation with my team interesting.
 I found it interesting that engineers go through so many iterations before creating a final product.
 The most interesting part of class was the use of pros and cons to identify a good solution. 
 This whole assignees very interesting I greatly enjoy the using real world problems as o assignments 
 I found working on the assignment to be the most interesting because I was able to connect with my team members and for me I struggle with that. It felt nice to be able to work together to achieve a goal and I found it interesting how our ideas were flowing together. 
 That we have a reading day next week and an assignment is being pushed back.
 that there are coffee makers that are in the form of a cup.

 I thought that discussing pros and cons and the importance of thought experiments was very valuable in today's class.

 I really like learning anout pro's and con's and why it is important to consider them. I liked this because we will use this skill throughout our entire career. 
 Our ideas could be as outrageous as we can make them.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on carbon emissions engaging and relevant, with many finding it interesting to learn about their personal and vehicular carbon footprints. The in-class activity of calculating CO2 emissions per mile for their cars was particularly impactful, with several students expressing surprise at the results. The discussion on design trade-offs and the importance of considering environmental impact in engineering was also well-received. Many students appreciated the practical application of these concepts to their ongoing project and the real-world relevance of the topic. Additionally, several students found the websites and visuals showcasing the effects of climate change and global warming to be striking and informative.

suggestion:
**Suggestions:**

1. **Focus on Personal Impact**: Highlight the students' realization of their personal contributions to climate change. This was a recurring theme in their reflections. For instance, "What I found most interesting... was the amount of everyday life that contributes to your personal carbon footprint." Emphasize this in the summary to make it more impactful.

2. **Clarify the Role of Engineers**: While the original summary mentions the role of engineers, it could be more explicit. Many students appreciated the discussion on how engineers can mitigate climate change. Consider revising the summary to emphasize this, e.g., "Students also appreciated understanding the role of engineers in combating climate change through design trade-offs and considering environmental impacts in projects."

3. **Simplify the Language**: Some phrases in the original summary could be simplified to make it more concise and focused. For example, instead of "resonated with them," consider "caught their attention" or "stuck with them." Also, instead of "engaging," consider "informative" or "eye-opening" to better reflect the students' experiences.
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the climate change lecture informative and eye-opening, particularly when calculating their personal and vehicular carbon footprints. Many realized the significant impact of their daily lives on their personal carbon footprint, with one student noting, "I took the survey... to determine my own [carbon footprint]," and another finding it "interesting to see the impact I have on the world." Interactive activities, such as the in-class car CO2 emission analysis and websites visualizing climate change impacts, caught their attention. Students also appreciated understanding the role of engineers in combating climate change through design trade-offs and considering environmental impacts in projects. One student summed it up, "It was interesting to learn how engineers have to take into account everything that is going on in the world around them and apply that to the job they are doing."

pred: **SUMMARY:** Students found today's class clear and straightforward, with a few exceptions. The project's goals and timeline were confusing to some, with concerns about the workload and the short timeframe. The distinction between criteria and constraints, as well as identifying stakeholders, also caused confusion. Some students sought more clarity on the assignment details for A16, particularly regarding which sections were due. Additionally, there was uncertainty about how to gather data for the project and how to empathize with diverse users, especially for online students. Lastly, a few students found the repetition of activities confusing.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding prototyping and testing processes, particularly for virtual or CAD-generated prototypes. Key concerns included determining the level of detail required for prototypes, selecting appropriate materials, and developing effective testing protocols. Some students struggled with the idea of testing virtual prototypes, while others found it challenging to test large-scale ideas with limited materials. A few teams also had difficulty understanding how to create and test prototypes remotely due to team members being off-campus. Students suggested that examples of strong experiments and testing protocols could help clarify these processes.
input:
Today's class was little confusing and I didn't need any extra details.
Prototyping 
The prototype section, specifically testing, is VERY confusing. My team is unsure how we are supposed to test our prototypes, especially if they are created using CAD software. Without purchasing materials, I'm unsure what could be used to create and test our solutions.
How detailed we need to be in our prototypes. 
Finding ways to develop a prototype for our idea 
I was confused about how to make a prototype for one of our designs originally. 
Nothing was confusing in today's class
I didn't get what materials i should use for prototype 
Something that could use more details in today's class was the schedule with our new reading day, because you went over it kind of quick and I didn't catch all the dates. 
We as a team found it difficult to find out not only how we would build a prototype, and how to test it. Unless we make them individually, physical prototypes aren't really feasible due to our separation. Additionally we couldn't figure out doable but also reliable ways to test our prototypes. 
 I thought the most difficult aspect of today's class was determining how to prototype our ideas to show the functionality of them.
 How we should develop a testing protocol is unclear. I don't remember going over it in the video modules and it isn't explained in the technical brief or assignment 17 instructions. I think going through an example of a testing protocol for the smart recycling bins would have been beneficial to the teams' understanding of what a testing protocol is and how to develop an effective one. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how my group will make the prototypes and test them in life. This was confusing for us because one of our team members is off campus, so we need to figure out how to test the prototypes and how we are making them.
 Everything made sense into today's class. But I wish there was more explanation to the ways we could create prototypes if the software option was not available to use. Other than that, everything made sense.
 I found it interesting the different types of modeling that could be used
 What was confusing was how the prototypes the groups create will be tested. My group was having a hard time understanding how this would be done virtually and with models of our design (given we don't have the ability to make real models of our prototype with the materials we wanted)
 The details for the assignment was confusing to me. The team was confused on what CAD software to use and some of the other elements of the assignment. I think after the slides are posted we will be able to review it and answer our questions.
 A confusing thing was the building of prototypes. It was confusing because of the use of materials that aren't easily accessible.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the prototyping phase of the design process engaging and beneficial. They appreciated learning about various prototyping methods, from simple sketches to advanced CAD software and 3D printing. Group work and brainstorming sessions were highlighted as valuable for generating ideas and refining prototypes. Students also expressed excitement about testing and evaluating their prototypes, with some mentioning the use of surveys and Purdue's resources like CAD software and 3D printing labs. Overall, prototyping was seen as a crucial step that allowed students to explore, test, and improve their designs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture's focus on brainstorming ideas and creating solutions engaging and relevant to their engineering studies. The use of biomimicry as a problem-solving approach also sparked curiosity, particularly in the examples of snakes and beetles. Some students found the topic confusing initially but appreciated its practical implications. Overall, students felt they were learning valuable skills that would be useful throughout their engineering careers.

**Suggestions:**

1. **Clarify the Activity's Objective**: To make the activity more focused and less confusing, explicitly state the desired outcome. For example, "The goal of the activity was to practice identifying and comparing pros and cons of two products, regardless of personal experience with them."

2. **Provide Relevant Context**: Instead of just mentioning the products, provide some basic information about each coffee maker (e.g., how they work, their target users) to help students understand their pros and cons better.

refined_pred:
**REFINED SUMMARY:** Students found the in-class activity on comparing pros and cons of two coffee makers (Keurig and French press) somewhat challenging, primarily due to lack of personal experience with these products or insufficient background information. To enhance future activities, consider the following improvements:

1. **Clarify the Activity's Objective**: Clearly communicate that the goal is to practice identifying and comparing pros and cons of two products, focusing on understanding their features and benefits, rather than personal experience.

2. **Provide Relevant Context**: Offer brief descriptions of each coffee maker, their target users, and basic functionality to help students analyze their pros and cons more effectively. For example:
   - **Keurig**: A single-serve coffee maker popular for convenience and variety, often used in offices or homes with busy lifestyles.
   - **French Press**: A manual coffee brewing method that produces a full-bodied flavor, preferred by coffee enthusiasts who appreciate the ritual and control over brewing.

3. **Specify the Level of Detail**: To address varied expectations, provide a guideline for the pros and cons diagram: "Your pros and cons should be specific, relevant, and cover at least 4-5 points for each product. Consider factors like cost, convenience, taste, environmental impact, and maintenance."

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on Digital Library Blocks (DLBs) informative but challenging. They sought clarity on DLB's implementation, particularly the role of linked lists in connecting nodes and levels. The concept of multi-way Radix Sorting Trees (RSTs) also caused some confusion, especially the origin of the number 256. Students struggled to keep track of various runtimes and understand the variables involved in runtime analyses. They also inquired about the definition of a 'nodelet' in a DLB and whether every node in a linked list qualifies as one. Lastly, some students expressed understanding of the topic after revisiting it.

pred: SUMMARY: Students grasped the fundamentals of Red-Black Binary Search Trees (RB BSTs), understanding the insertion and deletion processes, including the necessary rotations (rotate left and right). They recognized that the total number of black edges to any leaf node is consistent, ensuring the tree remains balanced and maintains a worst-case runtime of O(log n) for all operations. They also appreciated the dynamic nature of these operations, noting that in some cases, violations of RB BST conditions must be created to later resolve them, leading to transitions between the three RB BST insertion states until the tree is corrected.

3. **Use Active Voice**: To make the summary more engaging and direct, consider using active voice. For example, instead of "Students found the lecture informative," consider "The lecture informed students."
refined_pred: **REFINED SUMMARY:** The lecture on proofs engaged students, who appreciated learning rules of inference such as modus ponens and modus tollens. However, they sought deeper exploration of these and other rules to solidify their understanding. Initially, students struggled with applying direct proof, contraposition, and contradiction, but reflection helped clarify these concepts. Students also expressed curiosity about the relationship between informal and formal proofs, wondering if informal proofs could contain formal-like statements. To improve, students requested more practice with rules of inference and clearer differentiation between types of proofs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion about several aspects related to inductors. Many struggled with understanding the direction of current via Lenz's law and applying it in problems involving integrals. The physical interpretation and units of Henry were also unclear. Some students found it challenging to differentiate between Uc and Ul, and to apply equations for finding current in RL circuits. The behavior of inductors in circuits, particularly their influence on voltage graphs and oscillations, was another source of confusion. Lastly, students were unsure about when to use 'current switched on' vs 'current switched off' equations and how to analyze series and parallel circuits involving inductors.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the lecture on phasors and graphs engaging, with many appreciating the visual representations and demonstrations. Key takeaways included understanding the relationships between inductors, capacitors, resistors, and EMF through graphing, and the concept of current leading or lagging EMF, with a negative phase angle indicating current leads. The oscilloscope and phasor diagrams were particularly helpful in understanding resonance, with students enjoying the practical application of these tools in problem-solving and experiments. The relationship between resistance (R), reactance (X), and impedance (Z) at resonance (X_L=X_C) was also a notable learning point. Students found the practice problems and conceptual questions beneficial, with the large screen graphs aiding comprehension. Overall, students found the topic interesting and less challenging than expected, with many enjoying the hands-on and visual aspects of the lecture.
